S4.T1.caption: Table 1: Statistics of ConceptNet entities in the OK-VQA dataset. ++ and + indicates the answer is an entity or relate to an entity.
S4.T1.table:
OK-VQA split ConceptNet Wikipedia
Total 15,040 ++ 8,684 57.7% ++ 5,682 37.8%
+ 3,266 79.5%
Train 11,508 ++ 7,091 61.6% ++ 4,754 31.6%
+ 2,227 81.0%
Test 6,915 ++ 4,548 65.8% ++ 3,169 45.8%
+ 1,186 82.9%
references:
First, we sort out 15,040 valid answers appeared in the OK-VQA dataset and match each answer to ConceptNet and Wikipedia entities. The dataset statistics is summarized in Tab. 1.
We noticed 57.7% out of all answers are the ConceptNet entities, while 37.8% are Wikipedia entities.
Therefore, we proceed with ConceptNet as the oracle KG and leave the exploration on Wikipedia or Wikidata as future work.
Then, we use ConceptNet api to look up related entities of the other answers and keep the ones with confidence score above 0.8.
On top of matching table we obtained so far, we correct any wrongly paired answer-entity by hand, the results of which are presented in Tab. 2.

We noticed 57.7% out of all answers are the ConceptNet entities, while 37.8% are Wikipedia entities.
Therefore, we proceed with ConceptNet as the oracle KG and leave the exploration on Wikipedia or Wikidata as future work.
Then, we use ConceptNet api to look up related entities of the other answers and keep the ones with confidence score above 0.8.
On top of matching table we obtained so far, we correct any wrongly paired answer-entity by hand, the results of which are presented in Tab. 2.

S5.T3.caption: Table 3: Node classification recall on schema graphs of different sizes.
S5.T3.table:
R𝑅R@1 R𝑅R@10 R𝑅R@100
100​n100𝑛100n 13.39% 38.77% 52.56%
500​n500𝑛500n 11.55% 36.94% 56.70%
1000​n1000𝑛1000n 22.72% 48.33% 62.92%
references:
Network Pruning.
To demonstrate the effectiveness of graph pruning module, we perform multi-label classification on schema graphs of various scales.
As shown in Tab. 3, node classification on 1000-node schema graphs achieves 62.92 R𝑅R@100, which is higher than 52.56 R𝑅R@100 of 100-node schema graphs.
We conclude that the size of 1,000 is suitable for our framework, which results in highest recall at top 100.
This indicates that the graph pruning stage can effectively remove noisy node from the schema graph and prepare a feasible scale of candidates for path sampling.

S5.T4.caption: Table 4: Ground truth distribution in schema graph. The labels ‘q’, ‘v’ indicate ground truths being the key nodes extracted from question and image. ‘n-1’ and ‘n-2’ represent neighbor nodes at one-hop and two-hop distance.
S5.T4.table:
q𝑞q v𝑣v n𝑛n-1 n𝑛n-2
Training Set 7.35% 11.53% 45.10% 22.89%
Testing Set 6.85% 11.86% 48.79% 23.38%
references:
In addition, we explore the distribution of distance from our defined key nodes to ground truth entities.
In Tab. 4, nearly all the answers can be retrieved within two steps, which again confirms that our schema graph construction is reasonable.

Modular Ablation.
We perform modular ablation analysis in Tab. 5.
The upper half of the table indicates results of node classification on the 1,000n schema graph, with ℒp​r​u​n​esubscriptℒ𝑝𝑟𝑢𝑛𝑒\mathcal{L}_{prune} supervising node encoding. The node-level predictions are obtained by computing cosine similarity between node features and multimodal query embedding.
The lower half contains results of path ranking on graphs pruned to 100-node. ℒp​r​u​n​esubscriptℒ𝑝𝑟𝑢𝑛𝑒\mathcal{L}_{prune} supervises node encoding for pruning while ℒc​l​ssubscriptℒ𝑐𝑙𝑠\mathcal{L}_{cls} supervises path ranking.

S5.T6.caption: Table 6: Accuracy (%) of classification baselines under close-set setting, indicating limited answer space of training and testing gt answers. R𝑅R@10 reported in ‘open’ column.
S5.T6.table:
Models Answer Space test partial open open
LXMERT 4,025 21.92 5.16 0.00
ViLBERT 4,025 38.78 9.84 0.00
MAVEx(ViL) [28] 5,020 35.20 10.69 0.60
MAVEx [28] 5,020 39.40 8.74 0.60
GATHER + w/ cls 5,020 38.24 11.02 0.72
GATHER (ours) 516,782 24.94* 7.60* 3.01*
references:
Additionally, we present result of our ablated model with a classifier GATHER + w/ cls in Tab. 6, to verify that schema graph construction can effectively distill knowledge.
We input the schema graph obtained after Sec. 3.1 and Sec. 3.2 into a GAT layer. With the same query encoder ViLBERT, we then predict answer distribution with the concatenation of encoded query and pooled graph representation.

Compared to our proposed open-set framework, we evaluate current SOTA methods under close-set setting on ConceptVQA and OK-VQA in Tab. 6.
The close-set answer spaces of ConceptVQA and OK-VQA are 4,025 and 5,020 respectively, which contain all candidates from train and test sets.
Our results (*) in the last row are obtained under open-set setting, which allows 100-fold increase in answer space.

As mentioned in Sec. 5.2, our proposed framework has the ability of predicting open-set answers from all 516,782 ConceptNet entities, while most counterparts perform classification on close-set answer candidates.
To make a fairer comparison with existing classification baselines, we examine our proposed GATHER on close-set answer candidates as the extended analysis of results in Tab. 6.
We propose a close-set setting that adapts the schema graph constructing process to recruit entities that appear in the 4,025 answer candidates only.
While building close-set schema graph, we still keep the visual and textual entities as key nodes, but only candidate entities can be retrieved as 𝒱Nsubscript𝒱𝑁\mathcal{V}_{N} in the schema graph.
A similar path sampling rule is also applied.
As portrayed in Fig. 3, the ground truth hit rate of close-set schema graph achieves 80% at graph size of 500, and 87% at 1,000.
To keep consistency with the hit rate of 72.5% for 1,000-node open-set schema graph, we report performance on close-set schema graphs of size 500.

In comparison, we performed an open-set experiment on two baseline methods LXMERT and VilBERT to simulate the open-set setting.
Both methods uses all ground truth answers appeared in training and testing data as the answer space which is 4,025 answers in our constructed ConceptVQA.
But the classifier predict correct answer for none of the open questions, as reported in Tab. 6, .
To fill the gap in answer space size between the answer candidate and ConceptNet we use, we extend their answer space to a shuffled 50,000-class and then retrain the classifier.
LXMERT and VilBERT perform identically to their open-set results, which indicates that both classifiers learn biased answer distribution and are unable to answer open questions.

Sx1.T7.caption: Table 7: Effect of answer space and zero-shot questions.
Sx1.T7.table:
open / close ablation Top 1 Recall Rank by Node Rank by Path
full test partial open R𝑅R@10 R𝑅R@50 R𝑅R@100 R𝑅R@10 R𝑅R@20
open GATHER 24.94 7.60 49.47 60.45 63.07 42.26 48.71
close ℒp​r​u​n​esubscriptℒ𝑝𝑟𝑢𝑛𝑒\mathcal{L}_{prune} only 26.26 7.23 55.88 68.37 71.60 - -
GATHER 28.14 6.63 56.55 62.18 62.18 40.81 48.18
references:
In Tab. 7, we perform open-set and close-set experiments on ConceptVQA.
The close-set schema graph boost the accuracy on R@1, indicating narrowing down answer space would simplify the task.
Ablation experiments with close-set schema graphs result in similar patterns that path sampling and semi-hard triplet loss would increase accuracy.
The close-set models could achieve better performance if tested with a more specifically designed sampling module.

Sx5.T8.caption: Table 8: Open-set results of generative baselines. Open-set means model answers with open answers from KGs or large vocabulary bank.
Sx5.T8.table:
Models Answer Space Zero-shot Partial open*
Frozen [24] Vocab (32k) 5.9
FewVLMb​a​s​esubscriptFewVLM𝑏𝑎𝑠𝑒\text{FewVLM}_{base} [12] GPT-3 Vocab (50k) 11.6
PICaf​u​l​lsubscriptPICa𝑓𝑢𝑙𝑙\text{PICa}_{full} [30] GPT-3 Vocab (50k) 17.5 30.53
GATHER (ours) ConceptNet (516,782) - 7.60
references:
In Tab. 8, we present performance of our GATHER tested on ConceptVQA along with other generative baselines for Open-set KB-VQA.
Answer space of any generative method is the vocabulary size of the dependent language model, which is fixed unless re-training the entire backbone model.
Instead, our framework allows a bigger and more flexible answer space that varies with the size of the knowledge graph.
